summary: The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia today entered a final judgment against Jaclyn Tahboub, a Virginia resident who was diagnosed with an incompetent cervix during her first pregnancy.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia on December 22, 2016, Jaclyn reported severe pain and pain in her abdomen, legs, and lower back, which she had not experienced since her 2011 cerclage procedure.  The complaint alleges that the defendants failed to properly designate her expert witnesses and failed to adequately identify the cause of the pain and the possible effect of the infection on her health.  As alleged in the complaint, the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and Section 17(a)(1) and 17(b)(3) of Exchange Act Rules 10b2-1 and 17a-3 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC’s complaint, Shareef has consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and bars him from serving as an officer or director of a public company.  Shareef also agreed to be barred from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the alleged violations of the securities laws.  In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Shareef.   The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments in an investment in a real estate development project.Â The SEC encourages investors to check the backgrounds of people selling investments in real estate by using theÂ SEC's Investor.govÂ feature to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.  Investors can also use the SECÂ institutions.gov website to quickly and easily identify whether or not to invest in a specific investment.  For example, the SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Virginia Department of Health and Human Services in this matter. Â In a related matter, the Office of Inspector General has issued aÂ ComplaintÂ On December 26, 2018, the Court granted a temporary restraining order and ordered Shareef to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation of Jaclyn's death.
